name: Data Science Part Time Course
body:
General Assembly Data Science Course Repository

Course materials for [General Assembly's Data Science course](https://generalassemb.ly/education/data-science/Sydney/) **Location:** Level M, 56-58 York St Sydney NSW 2000 **Dates:** 21/03/2016 - 01/06/2016 **Instructors:** Ian Hansel **Teaching Assistant:** Matt Gibson **Schedule** Monday | Wednesday --- | --- 21/03: [Introduction](Class-1--Introduction) | 23/03: [Basics]() 28/03: Easter Break | 30/03: [Data Visualisation] 04/04: [Linear Regression] | 06/04: [Logistic Regression] 11/04: [Model Evaluaiton] | 13/04: [Regularisation] 18/04: [Clustering] | 20/04: [Recomendations & Associations] 25/04: Anzac Day | 27/04: [Dimensionality Reduction] 02/05: [Decision Trees] | 04/05: [Random Forests & Ensembling] 09/05: [Cloud Computing] | 11/05: [Natural Language Processing & APIs] 16/05: [Time Series] | 18/05: [Less Technical Skills - Communication] 23/05: [Graphs & Network Analysis] | 25/05: [Neural Networks & Deep Learning] 30/05: [Course Review & Project Presentations] | 01/06: [Project Presentations] --- ## Pre-Work ### Installation and Setup * Install the [Anaconda distribution](http://continuum.io/downloads) of Python 2.7x. * Install [Git](http://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Getting-Started-Installing-Git) and create a [GitHub](https://github.com/) account. * Once you receive an email invitation from [Slack](https://slack.com/), join our "SYD\_DAT\_4 team" and add your photo! ### Resources * [PEP 8 - Style Guide for Python](http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0008) ### Readings * Read the first two chapters of [The Data Science Handbook](http://www.thedatasciencehandbook.com/) * Read the first two chapters of an [Introduction to Statistical Learning][http://www-bcf.usc.edu/~gareth/ISL/ISLR%20Fourth%20Printing.pdf] ### Optional You're also more than welcome to do the following if you're keen to get extra advanced for your first class: * [Python Codecademy course](https://www.codecademy.com/learn/python) * Chapters 1, 2 and 5 of [Python for Data Analysis](http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920023784.do) * [Learn Python the Hard Way](www.learnpythonthehardway.org ) * [Command Line Crash Course](http://cli.learncodethehardway.org/book/) * [Khan Academy on Probability](https://www.khanacademy.org/math/probability) --- ##Course Project Information The final project should represent significant original work applying data science techniques to an interesting problem. Final projects are individual attainments, but you should be talking frequently with your instructors and classmates about them. Address a data-related problem in your professional field or a field you're interested in. Pick a subject that you're passionate about; if you're strongly interested in the subject matter it'll be more fun for you and you'll produce a better project! Look at [past projects](https://github.com/ihansel/SYD_DAT_4/tree/master/project-examples) on github for some ideas. --- ## Class 1: Introduction * Introduction to General Assembly * Course overview: our philosophy and expectations ([slides](slides/01_course_overview.pdf)) * Tools: check for proper setup of Git, Anaconda, overview of Slack **Homework:** * Resolve any installation issues before next class. * Make sure you have a github profile and created a repo called "SYD_DAT_4" * Clone the class repo (this one!) * Review this [code](code/00_python_refresher.py) for a recap of some Python basics. **Optional:** * Read [Analyzing the Analyzers](http://cdn.oreillystatic.com/oreilly/radarreport/0636920029014/Analyzing_the_Analyzers.pdf) for a useful look at the different types of data scientists. * Read about some [Markdown Techniques](http://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax) * Write a summary of 2 chapters of [The Data Science Handbook](http://www.thedatasciencehandbook.com/) in Markdown and submit a change request in the Lab Directory
note: Don't delete this file! It's used internally to help with page regeneration.
